title: The X Factor: Celebrity FIRST LOOK at the judges as Simon Cowell reunites with Nicole and Louis
text:
Advertisement

The X Factory: Celebrity is set to hit our screens in a few weeks, and ahead of the launch, the first official pictures of the judges have been revealed.

Simon Cowell reunites with former X Factor mentors Nicole Scherzinger and Louis Walsh, with both returning to help the find the next singing superstar. While Dermot O'Leary also steps back into his presenter's shoes.

And music mogul and the mastermind behind the singing extravaganza, Simon Cowell, reveals exactly why he decided to revamp the much-loved show.

Look who's back: The X Factory: Celebrity is set to hit our screens in a few weeks, and ahead of the launch, the first official pictures of the judges have been revealed

Promo images from the new show see former Pussycat Doll Nicole, 41, looking her usual glamorous self in a shimmering, tasselled dress as she stands between her fellow judges and host Dermot.

While the 14 all-star acts also pose up a storm in snazzy new images for the ITV show.

In an interview ahead of the launch, Simon, 60, revealed the reason why he decided to revamp the normal show into a celebrity version.

'It just felt so obvious to do a celebrity version', he explained. 'The only condition was I couldn’t know who was going to be on it. I said to the team, “You’ve got to find some acts who you believe can sell records off the back of this, because if you don’t do that it won’t work.”

New idea: 'It just felt so obvious to do a celebrity version', he explained. 'The only condition was I couldn’t know who was going to be on it'

'So that was the deal and we stuck to it. I swear to God I didn’t have a clue who any of the acts were. I did walk away thinking, “If we’re smart, we have artists here who could actually sell records off the back of this”. So I thought that was fun and very exciting for the show.'

The music boss also shared how he felt about holding the auditions in his own back garden.

He said: 'When we filmed it that night it didn’t feel like work. I loved every second of it. I said to the producers, “If this really doesn’t work, we will have to re-audition for the show. That’s the deal.”

'So the fact that I felt we didn’t need to was just great. I found it interesting and fun, and doing this version of the show has also given me the chance to do All Stars. I’ve wanted to make the best of the best version of The X Factor for a long, long time. It’s been brilliant. I’ve loved every minute.'

Unexpected: 'What we’re doing this year I think is a brilliant idea. I think everyone’s going to love watching these celebrities because it’s not what people expect. Some of them are really good'

Battle: The Don't Hold Your Breath hitmaker ensured that she'll be as competitive as ever this year. 'Oh always!' she insisted. 'You can’t take that out of me! I’m just going to be very supportive

Meanwhile, returning judge Louis, 67, revealed why he's so excited about the show, adding that the contestants are not what people will expect.

He said: 'What we’re doing this year I think is a brilliant idea. I think everyone’s going to love watching these celebrities because it’s not what people expect. Some of them are really good.

'The show feels more exciting, there’s no bootcamp, no six chair challenge, it feels slick this year. It’s been the best show on TV for a long time and has just had a little rebranding, I suppose, a new X Factor.'

While Nicole explained why the celebrity version differs from the civilian edition.

She explained: 'Obviously it’s a lot shorter, which is the difference between The X Factor: Celebrity and the ones in the past. This one doesn’t have boot camp and all that jazz, and I loved that we just cut straight to the chase. I was really excited to see who the celebrities were going to be.'

Trusting: 'I think the same as him in many ways. You’ve always got to trust him. That’s the thing. No one’s infallible but his instinct is more often than not right. I think it’s a good shout'

Big plans: 'People think that I sang in Hairspray. I did not sing in Hairspray. The original movie was all about dancing. So yeah, I’m hoping maybe one of those doors opens when people see me on the The X Factor'

And the Don't Hold Your Breath hitmaker ensured that she'll be as competitive as ever this year.

'Oh always!' she insisted. 'You can’t take that out of me! I’m just going to be very supportive.

'This year I think the way Simon has done it is that we help them and support them. In the past when I did it, I was quite hands-on and did a lot. But I’m ready to see what they are going to bring to this show.'

Elsewhere, front man Dermot, 46, revealed what he thought when Simon decided to rip up the rule book and do a celebrity version of The X Factor.

He said: 'I think the same as him in many ways. You’ve always got to trust him. That’s the thing. No one’s infallible but his instinct is more often than not right. I think it’s a good shout.

New career? I’ve made the headline on several occasions but I’m here because I’m 56 and I would love the opportunity to develop a second career'

Chat: The Chase star Jenny Ryan described the show as a 'proper departure' and a 'real adventure', while former Coronation Street actress Victoria Ekanoye says that although she's a TV star, 'music was always my first love'

Jitters: 'Wow, it’s a big deal because I just think Simon could say one thing and it can make people change their mind about you, you know?'

'Everyone I’ve spoken to about it, whether they’re my friends or taxi drivers or what not has gone, “That’s exciting!”. I think it’s fun. It feels like there’s something special happening.'

Meanwhile, as the judges posed for new look snaps, so to did the acts taking part in the competition.

This series, like the civilian version, will see the acts split into three groups; the overs, the unders and the groups.

Leading the overs is a blast from the past, in the form of ex chat show host Ricki Lake, who is hoping to impress with her vocals.

And Ricki took the opportunity to shut down claims that she performed in Broadway, adding that if her X Factor stint does go well, she would actually like to hit the big stage.

She explained: 'People think that I sang in Hairspray. I did not sing in Hairspray. The original movie was all about dancing. So yeah, I’m hoping maybe one of those doors opens when people see me on the The X Factor.

Proud parent: My dad is super excited. He literally gets emotional just thinking about the fact that he gets to see me back on stage. He knows how much I love the stage. I am my father’s daughter completely'

Support: Former EastEnders star Jonny Labey said he hopes fans of the soap will support him as they are so 'loyal', while Love Actually star Olivia Olson said one of the reasons she's doing the show is because 'I’ve felt a little stuck in my career.'

Been there, done that: 'So during Glee, we performed on The X Factor in the UK, and I remember meeting Simon before, and he was super, super nice'

'My entire career has been about the next thing. It was never a calculated move, it was always like this came in front of me and do I want to go for it? Yes.'

The Chase star Jenny Ryan described the show as a 'proper departure' and a 'real adventure', while former Coronation Street actress Victoria Ekanoye says that although she's a TV star, 'music was always my first love.'

Meanwhile journalist Martin Bashir revealed why he wanted to do the competition, explaining: 'I’ve reported on some of the biggest stories in the past 30 years and been very fortunate because I’ve made the headline on several occasions but I’m here because I’m 56 and I would love the opportunity to develop a second career.

Elsewhere in the unders, former TOWIE star Megan McKenna, 27, has already forged a singing career of her own as a country singer.

But the reality beauty revealed that she's nervous to perform in front of Simon, saying: 'Wow, it’s a big deal because I just think Simon could say one thing and it can make people change their mind about you, you know?

Island singing: Elsewhere, Love Island supergroup, consisting of Eyal Booker, Wes Nelson, Samira Mighty and Zara McDermott, told how they discovered each other could sing while starring on the show

'I think a lot of people listen to Simon’s opinions, but I really respect Simon. I always have. I would love to work with him. I just hope he likes my music.'

Hayley Hasselhoff also told how her famous dad David Hasselhoff is excited to for her to do the show, the the Knight Rider star even getting emotional just thinking about it.

She said: 'My dad is super excited. He literally gets emotional just thinking about the fact that he gets to see me back on stage. He knows how much I love the stage. I am my father’s daughter completely.

Former EastEnders star Jonny Labey said he hopes fans of the soap will support him as they are so 'loyal', while Love Actually star Olivia Olson said one of the reasons she's doing the show is because 'I’ve felt a little stuck in my career.'

Different path: Meanwhile, rugby hunk Bed Foden, of sport star group Try Star, revealed his career would have been very different if he followed his first love of singing

While everyone is nervous to perform in front of Simon, Kevin McHale revealed that he's already had that honour in the past.

He explained: 'So during Glee, we performed on The X Factor in the UK, and I remember meeting Simon before, and he was super, super nice. The whole illusion of him being really awful, so it had sort of faded for me, but then we were on that stage singing, and I knew we weren’t being judged but I still couldn’t look at him. I was like, “Oh God.”

Elsewhere, Love Island supergroup, consisting of Eyal Booker, Wes Nelson, Samira Mighty and Zara McDermott, told how they discovered each other could sing while starring on the show.

Wes said: ' In the villa, we all knew that we could sing because we were singing all the time, we never shut up.'

As Eyal added: 'Yeah, Wes would sing in the shower, him and Samira would harmonise and stuff together. Then we’d all get involved!'

Unphased: Social media stars Max and Harvey admitted that they are not scared of what Simon will say. They said: 'I think we’ll be able to take it as constructive criticism. I don’t think anything that he can say will ever put us off'

Meanwhile, rugby hunk Bed Foden, of sport star group Try Star, revealed his career would have been very different if he followed his first love of singing.

He said: 'I’ve always been a bit of a singer. When I got to the age of 17 I had to decide whether to go into professional sport or not. If I didn’t get a professional contract in rugby, I was going to go to London and go to a performance school.

'I was going to venture down that path, but obviously the rugby got in the way of that and I spent the last 15 years playing rugby instead of trying my hand at music.'

Social media stars Max and Harvey meanwhile admitted that they are not scared of what Simon will say about their performances.

Opinionated: 'You’ve got to know your place in the chain, and my place in this chain is not, “I know what’s best.” I can’t promise that I will bite my tongue'

So lovely: 'The other celebrities were so awesome, I thought they were very cool and easy to talk to. Of course, it’s so scary going into a room with all the contestants and not knowing any of them personally but it was super chill'

They told: 'I think we’ll be able to take it as constructive criticism. I don’t think anything that he can say will ever put us off.'

Speaking of Simon, former Strictly star Brendan Cole, of group Cole & Edwards, confessed that he may not be able to hold his tongue when Simon criticises them.

Famously known for his opinionated demeanour on Strictly, he said: 'You’ve got to know your place in the chain, and my place in this chain is not, “I know what’s best.” I can’t promise that I will bite my tongue. I haven’t been able to promise that in the last 43 years, so I won’t start making promises now.'

Finally, Wendii, from V5, was quick to gush over her fellow competitors, describing them as 'cool' and ;'awesome'.

She said: 'The other celebrities were so awesome, I thought they were very cool and easy to talk to. Of course, it’s so scary going into a room with all the contestants and not knowing any of them personally but it was super chill.'

The X Factor: Celebrity starts Saturday 12th October 8:35pm on ITV.
description: The first look at the X Factor: Celebrity judges as Simon Cowell reunites with Nicole Scherzinger and Louis Walsh as the music mogul reveals why he's revamped the singing show
